'''Gabriel Steve Lopez''' (January 16, 1978 – January 25, 2026) was an American pop-rock singer/songwriter and producer. He was of [[Mexican people|Mexican]] and [[Irish people|Irish]] descent. Signed to [[Universal Music Group]] as a songwriter and to Spectra Music Group as an artist, Lopez produced and wrote for [[Belinda Carlisle]], [[New Kids on the Block]], [[James Brown]], [[The Go-Go's]], ''[[RuPaul's Drag Race]]'', [[Twice]], [[Krayzie Bone]], [[Shinee]], [[Super Junior]], [[Tae Yang]], [[Charice]] as well as for television and film.
'''Gabriel Steve Lopez''' (January 16, 1977 – January 25, 2026) was an American pop-rock singer/songwriter and producer. He was of [[Mexican people|Mexican]] and [[Irish people|Irish]] descent. Signed to [[Universal Music Group]] as a songwriter and to Spectra Music Group as an artist, Lopez produced and wrote for [[Belinda Carlisle]], [[New Kids on the Block]], [[James Brown]], [[The Go-Go's]], ''[[RuPaul's Drag Race]]'', [[Twice]], [[Krayzie Bone]], [[Shinee]], [[Super Junior]], [[Tae Yang]], [[Charice]] as well as for television and film.

'''Cyclononatetraene''' is an [[organic compound]] with the formula C<sub>9</sub>H<sub>10</sub>. It was first prepared in 1969 by protonation of the corresponding aromatic anion (described below).<ref name=Radlick1969>{{Cite journal|last1=Radlick|first1=Phillip|last2=Alford|first2=Gary|date=November 1969|title=Preparation and isolation of <em>cis</em>,<em>cis</em>,<em>cis</em>,<em>cis</em>-1,3,5,7-cyclononatetraene|journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society|language=EN|volume=91|issue=23|pages=6529–6530|doi=10.1021/ja01051a083|issn=0002-7863}}</ref> It is unstable and isomerizes with a half-life of 50 minutes at room temperature to {{ill|3a,7a-dihydro-1H-indene|lt=3a,7a-dihydro-1''H-''indene|qid=Q82347715|s=1}} via a thermal 6π disrotatory electrocyclic ring closing.<ref name=Radlick1969/> Upon exposure to ultraviolet light, it undergoes a photochemical 8π electrocyclic ring closing to give bicyclo[6.1.0]nona-2,4,6-triene.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Houben-Weyl Methods of Organic Chemistry Vol. E 17b, 4th Edition Supplement: Carbocyclic Three-Membered Ring Compounds, Cyclopropanes: Synthesis|editor1-last=de Meijere|editor1-first=Armin|publisher=Georg Thieme Verlag|year=2014|isbn=978-3131819543|location=Goettingen|pages=1226}}</ref>
'''Cyclononatetraene''' is an [[organic compound]] with the formula C<sub>9</sub>H<sub>10</sub>. It was first prepared in 1969 by protonation of the corresponding aromatic anion (described below).<ref name=Radlick1969>{{Cite journal|last1=Radlick|first1=Phillip|last2=Alford|first2=Gary|date=November 1969|title=Preparation and isolation of <em>cis</em>,<em>cis</em>,<em>cis</em>,<em>cis</em>-1,3,5,7-cyclononatetraene|journal=Journal of the American Chemical Society|language=EN|volume=91|issue=23|pages=6529–6530|doi=10.1021/ja01051a083|issn=0002-7863}}</ref> It is unstable and isomerizes with a half-life of 50 minutes at room temperature to {{ill|3a,7a-dihydro-1H-indene|lt=3a,7a-dihydro-1''H-''indene|qid=Q82347715|s=1}} via a thermal 6π disrotatory electrocyclic ring closing.<ref name=Radlick1969/> Upon exposure to ultraviolet light, it undergoes a photochemical 8π electrocyclic ring closing to give {{ill|cis-Bicyclo(6.1.0)nona-2,4,6-triene|lt=''cis''-bicyclo[6.1.0]nona-2,4,6-triene|qid=Q82745886|s=1}}.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Houben-Weyl Methods of Organic Chemistry Vol. E 17b, 4th Edition Supplement: Carbocyclic Three-Membered Ring Compounds, Cyclopropanes: Synthesis|editor1-last=de Meijere|editor1-first=Armin|publisher=Georg Thieme Verlag|year=2014|isbn=978-3131819543|location=Goettingen|pages=1226|url=https://archive.org/details/methodenderorgan0017bunse/page/1226/mode/2up?q=cyclononatetraene}}</ref>

The '''Kevin Heffernan Stakes''' is a [[Melbourne Racing Club]] [[Group races|Group 3]] [[Thoroughbred]] [[weight for age]] [[horse race]], for horses aged three years old and upwards, over a distance of 1,400 metres held at [[Sandown Racecourse]], [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.racingandsports.com.au/thoroughbred/feature-race/australia/kevin-heffernan-stakes/664|title=Kevin Heffernan Stakes | Past Winners | Results | Australia | Racing and Sports}}</ref>
The '''Kevin Heffernan Stakes''' is a [[Melbourne Racing Club]] [[Group races|Group 3]] [[Thoroughbred]] [[weight for age]] [[horse race]], for horses aged three years old and upwards, over a distance of 1,400 metres held at [[Caulfield Racecourse]] and previously at [[Sandown Racecourse]], [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.racingandsports.com.au/thoroughbred/feature-race/australia/kevin-heffernan-stakes/664|title=Kevin Heffernan Stakes | Past Winners | Results | Australia | Racing and Sports}}</ref>

==History==

In 2013 the event was held at [[Caulfield Racecourse]] due to construction at Sandown Racecourse.<ref name="AT_Caulfield">{{cite web|url=http://www.racingandsports.com.au/en/press-room/2013-14-victorian-race-dates-story-272532|title=2013-14 Victorian Race Dates|work=racingandsports.au.com (Aus)|date=12 March 2013|accessdate=10 November 2014|archive-date=8 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141108223128/http://www.racingandsports.com.au/en/press-room/2013-14-victorian-race-dates-story-272532|url-status=dead}}</ref>
In 2013 the event was held at [[Caulfield Racecourse]] due to construction at Sandown Racecourse.<ref name="AT_Caulfield">{{cite web|url=http://www.racingandsports.com.au/en/press-room/2013-14-victorian-race-dates-story-272532|title=2013-14 Victorian Race Dates|work=racingandsports.au.com (Aus)|date=12 March 2013|accessdate=10 November 2014|archive-date=8 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141108223128/http://www.racingandsports.com.au/en/press-room/2013-14-victorian-race-dates-story-272532|url-status=dead}}</ref>


In 2021 and 2022 the race was run at [[Caulfield Racecourse]].<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.racenet.com.au/amp/news/melbourne-racing-club-ready-to-test-the-delayed-herald-sun-zipping-classic-at-caulfield-on-saturday-20211122 |title=Revamped Zipping Classic ready for Caulfield test |publisher=racenet.com.au |accessdate=25 November 2021}}</ref>
From 2021 the race has been run at [[Caulfield Racecourse]].<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.racenet.com.au/amp/news/melbourne-racing-club-ready-to-test-the-delayed-herald-sun-zipping-classic-at-caulfield-on-saturday-20211122 |title=Revamped Zipping Classic ready for Caulfield test |publisher=racenet.com.au |accessdate=25 November 2021}}</ref>


Traditionally held in late November it was moved to early February in 2026.
Traditionally held in late November it was moved to early February in 2026.

Casablanca had the largest Jewish community in the Maghreb in the 20th century, as well more than 80 synagogues and many Jewish social, cultural, and charitable organizations.<ref name=":0">{{Citation |last=Levy |first=Andre |title=Encyclopedia of Jews in the Islamic World |date=1 Oct 2010 |url=https://referenceworks.brill.com/doi/10.1163/1878-9781_ejiw_COM_0005090 |access-date=2026-02-08 |chapter=Casablanca |language=en |doi=10.1163/1878-9781_ejiw_COM_0005090 |last2=Schroeter |first2=Daniel}}</ref>


== History ==
A [[Sephardic Jews|Sephardic Jewish]] community was in [[Anfa]] up to the destruction of the city by the Portuguese in 1468. Jews were slow to return to the town, but by 1750, the Rabbi Elijah [[synagogue]] was built as the first Jewish synagogue in Casablanca. It was destroyed along with much of the town in the [[1755 Lisbon earthquake]].<ref name="JVL">{{cite web |title=''Casablanca'' |url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/vjw/Casablanca.html |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717065408/http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/vjw/Casablanca.html |archive-date=17 July 2011 |access-date=17 April 2011 |publisher=Jewishvirtuallibrary.org}}</ref>

The adulteration of food had been practised in Britain since before the [[Middle Ages]], but from 1800, with increasing [[urbanisation]] and the rise in shop-purchased food, adulterants became a growing problem. With the cost of sugar high, replacing it with substitutes was common. For the sweets produced in Bradford, the confectioner was supposed to purchase [[Plaster#Gypsum plaster|powdered gypsum]], but a mistake at the wholesale chemist meant arsenic was purchased instead.
The adulteration of food had been practised in Britain since before the [[Middle Ages]], but from 1800, with increasing [[urbanisation]] and the rise in shop-purchased food, adulterants became a growing problem. With the cost of sugar high, replacing it with substitutes was common. For the sweets produced in Bradford, the confectioner was supposed to purchase [[Plaster#Gypsum plaster|powdered gypsum]], but a mistake at the wholesale chemist meant arsenic was purchased instead.


Three men{{Mdash}}the chemist who sold the arsenic, his assistant and the sweet maker{{Mdash}}were arrested but all acquitted after the judge decided that there was no case for any of them to answer as the entire poisoning was accidental. The deaths led to the [[Adulteration of Food or Drink Act 1860]], although the legislation was criticised for being too ambiguous and the penalties for breaching it too low to act as a deterrent. The deaths were also a factor in the passage of the [[Pharmacy Act 1868]].
Three men were arrested—the chemist who sold the arsenic, his assistant and the sweet maker—but all three were acquitted after the judge decided it was all accidental and there was no case for any of them to answer. The deaths led to the [[Adulteration of Food or Drink Act 1860]], although the legislation was criticised for being too ambiguous and the penalties for breaching it too low to act as a deterrent. The deaths were also a factor in the passage of the [[Pharmacy Act 1868]].

* /a, ɛ, i, ɔ, u/ have their long-version spelled with duplicated letters, except for /uː/ spelled with ⟨ou⟩ because Tunisians lacks a stable short version.
* Short vowel sounds from Arabic either disappear in Tunisian ("تُرَاب" : /t'''u'''raːb/ --> "traab" /traːb/ ("dirt") ), get lengthened ("هِبَة" : /h'''i'''ba/ --> "Hiibe" /h'''iː'''bə/ (proper name; "gift") ), or shifted ("هُدَى" : /h'''u'''daː/ --> "Hodee" /h'''ʊ'''dɛ/ (proper name; "guidance") )
* /ɪ, ʊ/ are inferred through the stable construction "VCC" or "VC#" where V is either ⟨e⟩ or ⟨o⟩, C is a consonant and # marks the end of a word.
* "sk'''e'''<u>t</u>" /sk'''ɪ'''t/ ("to keep silent"); "f'''o'''<u>rs</u>tek" /fʊrstɪk/ ("your chance"); "m'''o'''<u>dd</u>a" /mʊdːə/ ("a period", "a long time").
* A final ⟨e⟩ marks a schwa e.g.: "Torkia" /tʊrkjə/
* Tunisian developped a simple nasal system from French; where generally /ɑ̃/ and /ɔ̃/ converged into /ɔ̃/ and /œ̃/ and /ɛ̃/ into /ɛ̃/ both categories being respelled according for grammar-related purposes.
* Tunisian developped a simple nasal system from French; where generally /ɑ̃/ and /ɔ̃/ converged into /ɔ̃/ and /œ̃/ and /ɛ̃/ into /ɛ̃/ both categories being respelled according for grammar-related purposes.
* Graphemes followed by at least a consonant like ⟨en⟩, ⟨on⟩ and ⟨an⟩ – referring to non-French words "'''en'''ti", "k'''on'''tou" and "f'''an'''ta" –might cause an issue as they are not nazalized, but rather pronounced /ɪn/, /ʊn/ and /an/ respectively.
*

'''Sagunto''',{{efn|Pronunciation of Sagunto: <br /> {{IPA|es|saˈɣunto|lang}}}} or {{lang|ca-valencia|'''Sagunt'''}}{{efn|Pronunciation of ''Sagunt'': <br />{{IPA|ca-valencia|saˈɣunt|lang}}}} (officially: '''{{lang|ca-valencia|Sagunt}} / {{lang|es|Sagunto}}''', historically: {{lang|ca-valencia|'''Morvedre'''}}{{efn|Pronunciation of ''Morvedre'': <br /> {{IPA|ca-valencia|moɾˈveðɾe|lang}}}}), is a city and municipality of [[Spain]], located in the [[province of Valencia]], Valencian Community. It belongs to the modern fertile ''[[comarques of the Valencian Community|comarca]]'' of [[Camp de Morvedre]]. It is located approximately {{cvt|30|km}} north of [[Valencia]] city center. Lies on the [[Costa de Valencia]] on the [[Mediterranean Sea]].
'''Sagunto'''{{efn|Pronunciation of Sagunto: <br /> {{IPA|es|saˈɣunto|lang}}}} or {{lang|ca-valencia|'''Sagunt'''}}{{efn|Pronunciation of ''Sagunt'': <br />{{IPA|ca-valencia|saˈɣunt|lang}}}} (officially: '''{{lang|ca-valencia|Sagunt}} / {{lang|es|Sagunto}}''', historically: {{lang|ca-valencia|'''Morvedre'''}}{{efn|Pronunciation of ''Morvedre'': <br /> {{IPA|ca-valencia|moɾˈveðɾe|lang}}}}) is a [[city]] and [[municipality]] of [[Spain]], located in the [[province of Valencia]], Valencian Community. It belongs to the modern fertile ''[[comarques of the Valencian Community|comarca]]'' of [[Camp de Morvedre]]. It is located approximately {{cvt|30|km}} north of [[Valencia]] city center. Lies on the [[Costa de Valencia]] on the [[Mediterranean Sea]].


It is best known for the remains of the ancient [[Iberians|Iberian]] and Roman city of ''Saguntum''. The [[siege of Saguntum]] in 219 BC was the trigger of the [[Second Punic War]] between the Carthaginians and the Romans.

Kalangi Nathar is an immortal Siddha and a world-renowned teacher of [[alchemy]].<ref>{{Cite book |last=Mark amaru |first=Pinkham |url=https://www.google.co.in/books/edition/The_Return_of_the_Serpents_of_Wisdom/IspS46HFPv0C?hl=en&gbpv=1&dq=%22Kalangi+Nathar%22+-wikipedia&pg=PT194&printsec=frontcover |title=The return of the serpents of wisdom |publisher=Adventures Unlimited Press |year=2011 |isbn=9781935487371}}</ref> In China, Kalanginathar instructed Siddhar Bogar in all aspects of the Siddha sciences. These included the preparation and use of the [[kayakalpa]] herbal formulae to promote longevity. He is talented in the medicinal field and uses herbs to cure the diseases of his devotees.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Linker |first=Ione |title=Kaya kalpa and the alchemical tradition in ayurveda and siddha medicine |url=https://www.ayurvedacollege.com |publisher=California College of Ayurveda (2009)}}</ref> Bhogar Jnana Sagarama (Bhogar’s Oceanic Life Story, consisting of 557 verses, verse number 2, lines number 3 and 4), Bogar states that the great Siddha Kalangi Nathar initiated him in [[Jñāna yoga|Jnana Yoga]] (''Kriya Dhyana yogam'') - supreme self-knowledge. Bogar received initiation from the illustrious Natha Yogi, Kalangi. Contemplative insight allegedly guided Bogar to construct a primitive form of [[aircraft]] that he used in a journey to China.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Siddha Boganathar, An Oceanic Life Story |url=https://www.energyenhancement.org/BHOGAR-The-Tamil-Siddar-Kundalini-Yoga-Spiritual-Alchemy-THE-KUNDALINI-KEY-SUFI-DOME-MINARET-CHAKRAS-JHANAS-STUPA-BUDDHISM-ATLAS-GREEK-MYTH.htm |website=energyenhancement.org}}</ref>

At the end of his loan, Eibar exercised Cucurella's clause, making him a permanent player for the [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque]] team; along with the transfer, Barcelona added a €4 million buyback option.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://as.com/futbol/2019/05/27/primera/1558958774_939539.html |title=El Eibar ejerce la claúsula de compra de Marc Cucurella|trans-title=Eibar triggers Marc Cucurella's buyout clause |newspaper=Diario AS |language=es |date=27 May 2019}}</ref> On 16 July 2019, after just sixteen days as a permanent Eibar player, this clause was activated,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.beinsports.com/us/laliga/news/barcelona-buy-back-cucurella-from-eibar/1243811 |title=Barcelona Buy Back Cucurella From Eibar |publisher=beIN Sports |date=16 July 2019}}</ref> only for him to be loaned to [[Getafe CF|Getafe]] two days later for the upcoming season, with an option to buy for €6 million and 40% of the rights remaining to Barcelona.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/en/news/1288455/agreement-with-getafe-for-the-loan-of-marc-cucurella |title=Agreement with Getafe for the loan of Marc Cucurella |publisher=FC Barcelona |date=18 July 2019|access-date=18 July 2019}}</ref>

===Brighton and Hove Albion===
===Brighton and Hove Albion===
[[File:Manchester United v Brighton & Hove Albion, 15 February 2022 (26).jpg|thumb|right|Cucurella playing for [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] in 2022]]
On 31 August 2021, Cucurella joined [[Premier League]] club [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]] on a five-year contract.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.brightonandhovealbion.com/news/2239897/marc-cucurella-joins-from-getafe |title=Marc Cucurella joins from Getafe |publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. |date=31 August 2021 |access-date=31 August 2021 |archive-date=31 August 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210831152403/https://www.brightonandhovealbion.com/news/2239897/marc-cucurella-joins-from-getafe |url-status=dead }}</ref> He made his debut for Brighton on 11 September, starting and playing 82 minutes before being substituted in the 1–0 away win over [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/58436979 |title=Brentford 0–1 Brighton: Leandro Trossard scores last-minute winner for Seagulls |website=BBC Sport |date=11 September 2021|access-date=11 September 2021}}</ref> Eight days later, he made his home debut, playing the whole of the 2–1 victory over [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/58533950 |title=Brighton & Hove Albion 2–1 Leicester City: Seagulls hold off late pressure to go third |date=19 September 2021|access-date=19 September 2021 |website=BBC Sport}}</ref> His chipped cross set up [[Danny Welbeck]]'s headed equaliser in added time, finishing 1–1 away to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] on 29 December.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/59751273 |title=Chelsea 1–1 Brighton & Hove Albion: Danny Welbeck heads stoppage-time equaliser for Seagulls |date=29 December 2021|access-date=29 December 2021 |website=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 7 May 2022, he scored his first goal for the club; he netted the second of a 4–0 win over [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] by shooting from [[Leandro Trossard]]'s pull back.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/61281254 |title=Brighton 4–0 Manchester United: Big defeat ends United's Champions League hopes |website=BBC Sport |date=7 May 2022|access-date=7 May 2022}}</ref> Three days later, at the club's end of season awards, Cucurella won Players' Player of the Season as well as being voted Player of the Season.<ref name="Awards">{{cite news |url=https://www.brightonandhovealbion.com/news/2612228/cucurella-thanks-teammates-and-fans-for-awards |title=Cucurella thanks teammates and fans for awards |publisher=Brighton & Hove Albion F.C. |date=10 May 2022 |access-date=10 May 2022 |archive-date=18 April 2024 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240418150300/https://www.brightonandhovealbion.com/news/2612228/cucurella-thanks-teammates-and-fans-for-awards |url-status=dead }}</ref>

'''[[DOHaD]]''' '''China''', refers to Chinese participation in the '''[[International Society for Developmental Origins of Health and Disease]],''' an International [[non-profit organization|non-profit membership organization]] of researchers, clinicians, and health professionals focused on the developmental origins of health and disease.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-06-09 |title=Who We Are - Main - International DOHaD Society |url=https://dohadsoc.org/who-we-are/ |access-date=2026-02-07 |language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Hanson |first= |last2=Poston |first2= |last3=Gluckman |first3= |date=June 2019 |title=DOHaD – the challenge of translating the science to policy |url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/journal-of-developmental-origins-of-health-and-disease/article/dohad-the-challenge-of-translating-the-science-to-policy/37257D511F56BBBF85E91DB922A7FE82 |journal=Journal of Developmental Origins of Health and Disease |language=en |volume=10 |issue=3 |pages=263–267 |doi=10.1017/S2040174419000205 |issn=2040-1744}}</ref> It was set up in 2008 and made up of various [[scientists]] and clinicians (17 main [[council]] members).{{Citation needed|date=February 2026}}

Hungarian section: new section

← Previous revision Revision as of 08:01, 8 February 2026
Line 61: Line 61:
: Overall I think there are a couple of factors that make it hard to give a one-sentence summary of vowel harmony. First is that vowel harmony is very broad, and different languages can have vowel harmony in radically different ways. This makes anything that attempts to be accurate vague and anything that attempts to be specific inaccurate. The second is that a lot of (probably most) languages, including English, don't have vowel harmony in any form, and it's not intuitive rule if you only speak languages that don't have it.
: Overall I think there are a couple of factors that make it hard to give a one-sentence summary of vowel harmony. First is that vowel harmony is very broad, and different languages can have vowel harmony in radically different ways. This makes anything that attempts to be accurate vague and anything that attempts to be specific inaccurate. The second is that a lot of (probably most) languages, including English, don't have vowel harmony in any form, and it's not intuitive rule if you only speak languages that don't have it.
: Lastly I will point out that the page has dozens of examples of vowel harmony in the {{section link|Vowel harmony|Languages with vowel harmony}}. I'm not sure if you were suggesting moving these earlier in the article or something like that, but they do exist if you want to read them. [[User:AquitaneHungerForce|AquitaneHungerForce]] ([[User talk:AquitaneHungerForce|talk]]) 14:59, 27 January 2024 (UTC)
: Lastly I will point out that the page has dozens of examples of vowel harmony in the {{section link|Vowel harmony|Languages with vowel harmony}}. I'm not sure if you were suggesting moving these earlier in the article or something like that, but they do exist if you want to read them. [[User:AquitaneHungerForce|AquitaneHungerForce]] ([[User talk:AquitaneHungerForce|talk]]) 14:59, 27 January 2024 (UTC)

== Hungarian section ==

The Hungarian section appears poorly written. It constantly feels the need to reiterate that ⟨e a⟩ are unrelated to ⟨é á⟩, despite them clearly being short-long pairs, merely because the quality differs between the short [ɛ ɒ] and long [eː aː] forms. It refers to the acute as a "stick accent". Also, why does it use "cleft lip pronunciation" instead of just saying that those vowels are front? A vowel chart in the section has '"low"' and '"high"' in parentheses after 'back' and 'front'. It's full of nonsense. [[User:DdeWylvyn|DdeWylvyn]] ([[User talk:DdeWylvyn|talk]]) 08:01, 8 February 2026 (UTC)

==Battle==
==Battle==
Soon after Hostilius Mancinus took over command (who appears to have been equally as incompetent), the siege of Carthage was mostly eliminated; therefore, the Roman armies were engaged in various campaigns against smaller settlements in the interior and coast along with that of the Gulf of Carthage; thus, a coordinated assault both via land and sea against Clupea did not accomplish anything.{{sfn|Bagnall|1999|pp=315}} Neapolis was surrendered but subsequently sacked; however, Hippo Agra remained in action.{{sfn|Kern|1999|pp=291}} The Roman siege engines would subsequently be destroyed during a surprise attack by the enemy's defenders with help from the enemy's defenders; therefore, the Romans returned to their winter quarters located at Castra Cornelia (the site of Scipio Africanus' original camp).{{sfn|Bagnall|1999|pp=316}}{{sfn|Cook|1930|pp=481}}

'''Table Mountain''' ({{langx|naq|'''Huriǂoaxa'''|lit= sea-emerging}}; {{langx|af|'''Tafelberg'''}}) is a flat-topped [[mountain]] forming a prominent landmark overlooking the city of [[Cape Town]] in [[South Africa]].
'''Table Mountain''' ({{langx|naq|'''Huriǂoaxa'''|lit= sea-emerging}}; {{langx|af|'''Tafelberg'''}}) is a flat-topped [[mountain]] forming a prominent landmark overlooking the city of [[Cape Town]] in [[South Africa]].


It is a significant [[tourist attraction]], also Ivan Brcic was there in February 2026, with many visitors either using the [[Table Mountain Aerial Cableway|cableway]] or hiking to the top.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.vibescout.com/za/cape-town/table-mountain|title=Table Mountain in Cape Town|website=vibescout.com|language=en|access-date=2017-11-06|archive-date=6 July 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170706203210/https://www.vibescout.com/za/cape-town/table-mountain|url-status=live}}</ref> The mountain has 8,200 plant species, of which around 80% are [[fynbos]] (Afrikaans for 'fine bush').{{dub|date=January 2026}} [[Table Mountain National Park]] is the most visited national park in South Africa, attracting 4.2 million people every year for various activities.<ref>{{Cite web|title=33 cool facts about Table Mountain|url=http://www.news.uct.ac.za/article/-2015-03-09-33-cool-facts-about-table-mountain|access-date=2021-10-18|website=news.uct.ac.za|language=en|archive-date=20 October 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211020040202/https://www.news.uct.ac.za/article/-2015-03-09-33-cool-facts-about-table-mountain|url-status=live}}</ref> It forms part of the lands formerly inhabited by [[Khoe-Kwadi|Khoe-speaking]] clans, such as the {{lang|naq|!Uriǁʼaes}} (the "High Clan").
It is a significant [[tourist attraction]], with many visitors either using the [[Table Mountain Aerial Cableway|cableway]] or hiking to the top.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.vibescout.com/za/cape-town/table-mountain|title=Table Mountain in Cape Town|website=vibescout.com|language=en|access-date=2017-11-06|archive-date=6 July 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170706203210/https://www.vibescout.com/za/cape-town/table-mountain|url-status=live}}</ref> The mountain has 8,200 plant species, of which around 80% are [[fynbos]] (Afrikaans for 'fine bush').{{dub|date=January 2026}} [[Table Mountain National Park]] is the most visited national park in South Africa, attracting 4.2 million people every year for various activities.<ref>{{Cite web|title=33 cool facts about Table Mountain|url=http://www.news.uct.ac.za/article/-2015-03-09-33-cool-facts-about-table-mountain|access-date=2021-10-18|website=news.uct.ac.za|language=en|archive-date=20 October 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211020040202/https://www.news.uct.ac.za/article/-2015-03-09-33-cool-facts-about-table-mountain|url-status=live}}</ref> It forms part of the lands formerly inhabited by [[Khoe-Kwadi|Khoe-speaking]] clans, such as the {{lang|naq|!Uriǁʼaes}} (the "High Clan").


Table Mountain is home to a large array of mostly [[Endemism|endemic]] flora and fauna.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.capetownmagazine.com/table-mountain-facts|title=15 Things You Didn't Know About Table Mountain|date=2017|access-date=23 June 2017|archive-date=9 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150509202018/http://www.capetownmagazine.com/table-mountain-facts|url-status=live}}</ref> Its top rises about 1,000 m above the surrounding city, making the popular [[Hiking|hike]] upwards on a large variety of different, often steep and [[Rock (geology)|rocky]] pathways a serious [[Mountaineering|mountain tour]] which requires [[Physical fitness|fitness]], preparation and [[hiking equipment]].

Herodotus and Greek Perspectives: Rewrote section for encyclopedic tone and clarity. Removed WP:PEACOCK terms and editorializing. Contextualized Herodotus's accounts using existing citations (Hartog, Briant) without removing sources.

← Previous revision Revision as of 08:01, 8 February 2026
Line 27: Line 27:
The practice of ancient Iranian medicine underwent a transformation following [[Islamic conquest of Persia|Arab invasion]] (630 A.D.). However, the advances of the Sassanid period were continued and expanded upon during the flourishing of Islamicate sciences at Baghdad, with the Arabic text Tārīkh al-ḥukamā crediting the Academy of Gondishapur for establishing licensure of physicians and proper medical treatment and training. However, modern historians of medicine have challenged the traditional narrative regarding the existence of a formal medical academy at Gondishapur. Recent scholarship, including works by Peter Pormann and Emilie Savage-Smith, indicates that there is no contemporary pre-Islamic evidence for a medical school or a teaching hospital at Gondishapur. They suggest that later Islamic historians likely projected the institutional structures of the Abbasid era back onto the Sassanid past to legitimize the Galenic medical tradition.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Pormann |first1=Peter E. |last2=Savage-Smith |first2=Emilie |title=Medieval Islamic Medicine |publisher=Georgetown University Press |year=2007 |isbn=978-1589011618 |pages=42–43 |quote=There is no evidence that there was a formal medical school or a teaching hospital at Gundishapur.}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Dols |first=Michael W. |title=The Origins of the Islamic Hospital: Myth and Reality |journal=Bulletin of the History of Medicine |volume=61 |issue=3 |year=1987 |pages=367–390 |jstor=44443714}}</ref> Many [[Pahlavi scripts]] were translated into Arabic {{Citation needed|reason=Scholarly consensus indicates translations were primarily Greek and Sanskrit}} and the region of Greater Iran produced physicians and scientists such as Abū ʿAlī al-Ḥusayn ibn ʿAbd Allāh ibn Sīnā and Muhammad ibn Zakariya al-Razi as well as mathematicians such as Kharazmi and [[Omar Khayyám]].<ref>Birouni, Aussar el Baghieh</ref> They collected and systematically expanded the Greek, Indian, and Persian ancient medical heritage and made further discoveries.<ref>Mohammad-Hossein Azizi. History of Ancient Medicine in Iran. Arch Iranian Med 2007; 10 (4): 552–555.</ref>
The practice of ancient Iranian medicine underwent a transformation following [[Islamic conquest of Persia|Arab invasion]] (630 A.D.). However, the advances of the Sassanid period were continued and expanded upon during the flourishing of Islamicate sciences at Baghdad, with the Arabic text Tārīkh al-ḥukamā crediting the Academy of Gondishapur for establishing licensure of physicians and proper medical treatment and training. However, modern historians of medicine have challenged the traditional narrative regarding the existence of a formal medical academy at Gondishapur. Recent scholarship, including works by Peter Pormann and Emilie Savage-Smith, indicates that there is no contemporary pre-Islamic evidence for a medical school or a teaching hospital at Gondishapur. They suggest that later Islamic historians likely projected the institutional structures of the Abbasid era back onto the Sassanid past to legitimize the Galenic medical tradition.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Pormann |first1=Peter E. |last2=Savage-Smith |first2=Emilie |title=Medieval Islamic Medicine |publisher=Georgetown University Press |year=2007 |isbn=978-1589011618 |pages=42–43 |quote=There is no evidence that there was a formal medical school or a teaching hospital at Gundishapur.}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Dols |first=Michael W. |title=The Origins of the Islamic Hospital: Myth and Reality |journal=Bulletin of the History of Medicine |volume=61 |issue=3 |year=1987 |pages=367–390 |jstor=44443714}}</ref> Many [[Pahlavi scripts]] were translated into Arabic {{Citation needed|reason=Scholarly consensus indicates translations were primarily Greek and Sanskrit}} and the region of Greater Iran produced physicians and scientists such as Abū ʿAlī al-Ḥusayn ibn ʿAbd Allāh ibn Sīnā and Muhammad ibn Zakariya al-Razi as well as mathematicians such as Kharazmi and [[Omar Khayyám]].<ref>Birouni, Aussar el Baghieh</ref> They collected and systematically expanded the Greek, Indian, and Persian ancient medical heritage and made further discoveries.<ref>Mohammad-Hossein Azizi. History of Ancient Medicine in Iran. Arch Iranian Med 2007; 10 (4): 552–555.</ref>


=== Herodotus and Greek Perspectives ===
=== Ancient Greek Views of Pre Islamic Persian Medicine by Herodotus ===
Greek accounts, particularly the ''Histories'' of Herodotus (5th century BC), provide some of the earliest external descriptions of Persian health practices. While these accounts offer valuable details, modern historians note that they are often framed through the lens of Greek cultural norms and the political tensions of the Graeco-Persian Wars.<ref name="herodotus">{{Cite web |title=Herodotus, The Histories, Book 1, chapter 138, section 1 |url=https://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.01.0126:book=1:chapter=138:section=1 |access-date=2025-03-27 |website=www.perseus.tufts.edu}}</ref>
The Ancient Greeks often viewed Persian medicine with a contradictory combination of admiration and suspicion. This dynamic and attitude towards Persian medicine reflects the intellectual curiosity of the Greeks, anti-Persian biases and tensions between the two countries. Some Greek writers admired and respected Persian medicine, in particular, its surgery and lifestyle treatments, while some dismissed it for being overly religious, superstitious and dependent on magic, many more fall between these two extremes.


Herodotus highlights the Persian emphasis on ritual purity, which incidentally overlapped with hygienic practices. He notes that individuals with conditions resembling leprosy (white sickness) were isolated from the general population to prevent "pollution," a practice Herodotus attributes to the belief that the afflicted had "sinned against the sun."<ref name="herodotus" /> Similarly, he describes strict prohibitions against urinating, spitting, or washing hands in rivers, as water was revered as a sacred element.<ref name="herodotus" /> While Herodotus presents these as religious observances, they functioned as effective preventative health measures regarding water sanitation.
The earliest primary source from Ancient Greece that documents Persian Medicine is of the 5th Century BC, from Herodotus’ work ''Histories''. Herodotus records many Persian medicinal practices, most significant of which is Persian hygiene and preventative healthcare measures, concepts that are unprecedented so early on in human history. ''Histories'' contain occasional truthful depiction of Persian medical practices, however Herodotus’ Greek bias does appear often in some passages that mentioning foreign practices. Regardless, the source still provides valuable insight into what the ancient Greeks know and thought of Persian medicine. Herodotus notes in that Persian citizens with diseases like leprosy or white fever may not enter town and may, in some cases, even be cast out from town to avoid infection of others. Despite their flawed superstitious reasoning of believing disease was due to the infected person “sinning against the sun”,<ref name="herodotus">{{Cite web |title=Herodotus, The Histories, Book 1, chapter 138, section 1 |url=https://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.01.0126:book=1:chapter=138:section=1 |access-date=2025-03-27 |website=www.perseus.tufts.edu}}</ref> this shows that Persians have some concept of the infectiousness of diseases and preventative measures to combat diseases. This knowledge of the Persians have on hygiene is further reinforced upon in the same book and chapter where Herodotus notes that the rivers are especially revered by the Persians and they do not let anyone “urinate nor spit nor wash their hands”<ref name="herodotus" /> in their rivers to prevent pollution of the stream as part of ritual purity laws. The Persians caution when handling their water source shows their extensive knowledge of hygiene and the importance of a clean water supply, further establishing the Persian's advanced medical knowledge. Persian hygienic practices, although stemmed from false religious and superstitious beliefs, bring major health benefits to those who practice it as Herodotus observed, however these positive benefits were often overlooked and its false religious reasonings were often magnified due to the anti-Persian biases of Herodotus. This bias is well known and is echoed by François Hartog's book ''The Mirror of Herodotus'', where it states that anti Persian bias was often used by Herodotus as the “other” to form Greek cultural identity as a people.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Dewald |first=Carolyn |date=July 1990 |title=The Mirror of Herodotus: The Representation of the Other in the Writing of History. François Hartog , Janet Lloyd |url=https://doi.org/10.1086/367203 |journal=Classical Philology |volume=85 |issue=3 |pages=217–224 |doi=10.1086/367203 |issn=0009-837X|url-access=subscription }}</ref>


The ''Histories'' also document the presence of foreign physicians at the Achaemenid court, reflecting a pragmatic approach to healthcare. A notable example is the account of Darius I, who sustained a severe ankle injury. Herodotus reports that after Egyptian physicians failed to alleviate the king's pain, Darius turned to the Greek physician Democedes of Croton, who successfully treated the injury using Greek remedies.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Herodotus, The Histories, Book 3, chapter 129, section 3 |url=https://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.01.0126:book=3:chapter=129:section=3 |access-date=2025-03-27 |website=www.perseus.tufts.edu}}</ref> This narrative is often cited by scholars to illustrate the interaction between Greek and Persian medical traditions, though Herodotus uses it rhetorically to contrast Greek skill (''techne'') with what he portrays as the limitations of other traditions.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Herodotus, The Histories, Book 3, chapter 130, section 3 |url=https://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.01.0126:book=3:chapter=130:section=3 |access-date=2025-03-27 |website=www.perseus.tufts.edu}}</ref>
Another major Persian medical practice noted by Herodotus was their surprisingly modern and pragmatic approach to healthcare and medical infrastructure. Herodotus highlights that the Persians’ willingness to accept and adopt foreign medical practices, collaboration with foreign physicians regardless of their social rank and a robust compensation system for physicians. These traits are all very advanced for their time and are exemplified nowhere better than in the story of Democedes of Croton. Chapter 129-133 of ''Histories''’ Book 3 starts the story with the Persian king Darius I violently dislocating his ankle while hunting horseback, Egyptian physicians were summoned at first due to Egyptian physician's being seen as more medically specialized than Persian ones but to no avail despite a week of treatment.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Herodotus, The Histories, Book 3, chapter 129, section 2 |url=https://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.01.0126:book=3:chapter=129:section=2 |access-date=2025-03-27 |website=www.perseus.tufts.edu}}</ref> This shows the willingness and trust that Persians have for foreign physicians as seen when they allowed physicians from a rival country to treat their head of state. On the eighth day, Darius I  summoned Democedes, and he was found in chains and rags “among the slaves of Oroetes”,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Herodotus, The Histories, Book 3, chapter 129, section 3 |url=https://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.01.0126:book=3:chapter=129:section=3 |access-date=2025-03-27 |website=www.perseus.tufts.edu}}</ref> this also shows the Persians’ value of medical competence over social rank since they ignore Democedes being a slave and poor, a source of discrimination and common disqualifier for many pursuits in the ancient world. Herodotus claimed Democedes using Greek remedies instead of Egyptian ones healed Darius quickly and allowed him to sleep after a week of pain induced insomnia. However viewers must note that Herodotus and ''Histories'' have been known to have inconsistencies and exaggerations, with Herodotus’ personal biases often muddling the truth, as seen here where Herodotus characterized Greek remedies as “gentleness” and Egyptian ones as “violence”.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Herodotus, The Histories, Book 3, chapter 130, section 3 |url=https://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.01.0126:book=3:chapter=130:section=3 |access-date=2025-03-27 |website=www.perseus.tufts.edu}}</ref> This bias further extends to when Herodotus falsely faults the Persians’ incorporation of foreign physicians and uses it to highlight Persia's dependence on Greek and Egyptian doctors despite collaboration between doctors across nationalities often spurs medical progress. Herodotus also goes further with this to imply that Persia's dependence on foreign physicians despite their empire's great wealth was because of Persian medicine was not advance as its Greek and Egyptian counterparts, which was very untrue. For Democedes’ service, he was rewarded handsomely with golden fetters, a great sum of gold and a grand house,<ref>{{Cite web |title=Herodotus, The Histories, Book 3, chapter 130, section 4 |url=https://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.01.0126:book=3:chapter=130:section=4 |access-date=2025-03-27 |website=www.perseus.tufts.edu}}</ref> establishing that Persians had a concept of compensation for healthcare. This is further reinforced scholar Pierre Briant who asserts that the Persepolis Tablets prove that Persians had a well established state-sponsored healthcare system for workers and elites alike that pays healthcare workers for their services.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Briant |first=Pierre |url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/j.ctv1bxgwdk |title=From Cyrus to Alexander: A History of the Persian Empire |date=2002-07-21 |publisher=Penn State University Press |isbn=978-1-57506-574-8 |translator-last=Daniels |translator-first=Peter T. |doi=10.5325/j.ctv1bxgwdk |jstor=10.5325/j.ctv1bxgwdk }}</ref>


Despite the frequent employment of foreign doctors, Persepolis Fortification Tablets indicate the existence of a state-supported rationing system that included provisions for local health workers, suggesting an organized internal infrastructure beyond what Greek sources describe.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Briant |first=Pierre |url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/j.ctv1bxgwdk |title=From Cyrus to Alexander: A History of the Persian Empire |date=2002-07-21 |publisher=Penn State University Press |isbn=978-1-57506-574-8 |translator-last=Daniels |translator-first=Peter T. |doi=10.5325/j.ctv1bxgwdk |jstor=10.5325/j.ctv1bxgwdk }}</ref> Scholars like François Hartog argue that Herodotus's depictions, including those of the Magi's healing rituals, often served to construct a "barbaric other" against which Greek identity was defined, rather than serving as a purely objective medical record.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Dewald |first=Carolyn |date=July 1990 |title=The Mirror of Herodotus: The Representation of the Other in the Writing of History. François Hartog , Janet Lloyd |url=https://doi.org/10.1086/367203 |journal=Classical Philology |volume=85 |issue=3 |pages=217–224 |doi=10.1086/367203 |issn=0009-837X|url-access=subscription }}</ref>
The Persians’ preventative medical practices such as hygiene and clean water along with its forward thinking pragmatism in their willingness to collaborate with foreign physicians and to adopt foreign medical practices show how advanced their knowledge and approach to medicine was for its time. However, Herodotus contrasts this with his critique of some Persian medicinal practices with religious and superstitious roots as ineffective. Herodotus notably mentions the Persian incorporation of the Magi or religious ritual healers in the medical process, whose methods were ineffective. Herodotus notes the Magi “made offerings and cast spells”<ref>{{Cite web |title=Herodotus, The Histories, Book 7, chapter 191, section 2 |url=https://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.01.0126:book=7:chapter=191:section=2 |access-date=2025-03-27 |website=www.perseus.tufts.edu}}</ref> and sacrificed animals to ward of storms, diseases and other calamities. Herodotus implies the Persian use of Magi in medicine is theatrical, superstitious, and ineffective, paling in comparison to the rational Greek medicine. This notion was further reinforced when he highlighted how Democedes, a Greek slave, could heal Darius I's ankle quickly and effectively, when Egyptian and Persian physicians could not. However, Herodotus has made no mention Persian medicinal discoveries in medicinal herb use of sagapenon and surgery detailed in other primary sources at the time like Ctesias of Cnidus’ ''Persica''<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Engels |first=Johannes |date=April 2013 |title=Ctesias, On India and Fragments of his Minor Works. Introduction, Translation and Commentary by Andrew Nichols. London, Bristol Classical Press 2011 Ctesias On India and Fragments of his Minor Works. Introduction, Translation and Commentary by Andrew Nichols. 2011 Bristol Classical Press London € 21,99 |url=https://doi.org/10.1524/hzhz.2013.0125 |journal=Historische Zeitschrift |volume=296 |issue=2 |pages=471 |doi=10.1524/hzhz.2013.0125 |issn=0018-2613|url-access=subscription }}</ref> and also reinforced in archaeological findings of the Persepolis Tablets<ref>{{Cite book |last=Daneshmand |first=Parsa |title=The Encyclopedia of Ancient History |chapter=Persepolis Fortification Tablets |date=2021-10-13 |chapter-url=https://doi.org/10.1002/9781119399919.eahaa00389 |pages=1–2 |doi=10.1002/9781119399919.eahaa00389|isbn=978-1-119-39991-9 |chapter-url-access=subscription }}</ref> and Persian surgical tools. These criticisms and lack of acknowledgement of Persian medical innovations along with many instances of Herodotus portraying the Persian people and customs as irrational, barbaric, decadent and inferior to Greek counterparts show Herodotus’ strong anti-Persian biases. This is most likely due to the book being written after the Graeco-Persian Wars along with mutual xenophobia and hatred between the two countries due to their cultural divide. Hence, his criticisms of Persian medicine should be critically read with caution and cross examined with other primary sources whenever possible.

The Ancient Greek perspective on Persian medicine as recorded by Herodotus often heavily included anti-Persian biases, suspicion, mischaracterizations of Persian medicine being backwards, superstitious and reliant on foreign physicians and theatrical Magi rituals. Even when there were positive aspects of Persian medicine, theirs faults were often magnified as seen with the river hygiene taboos coming from religious reasons or outright omitted as seen with Persian medical breakthroughs in surgery and herbal medicine not being mentioned at all. Overall, Herodotus’ ''Histories'' provide great insight into Graeco-Persian relations during his time and reveal more about Greek attitudes towards Persians rather than the realities of Persian medicine. Despite the Greek anti-Persian mischaracterizations by Herodotus, Ancient Persia did have some valuable and valid contributions to medical knowledge that was very forward thinking, which would be adopted and refined by the Greeks themselves, the Romans and future civilizations.

== Collaboration with Cem Adrian ==
== Collaboration with Cem Adrian ==
A significant milestone in Goker’s career was her collaboration with Turkish musician Cem Adrian. She contributed as a composer and pianist to a track featured on Adrian’s album ''Mucevher''. This collaboration increased her recognition within professional music circles.
